results.title: A Taste of honey
results.creator_credit: Tony Richardson, Woodfall Film Productions, Continental and Bryanston Films
results.brief_description: A kitchen sink drama from the early 1960s, “A Taste of Honey” is about a young Englishwoman, who lives with her hard drinking, floozy of a mother, Helen. When Helen impulsively marries her current boyfriend, Jo is turned out and moves in with Geoffrey, a kindly homosexual friend, himself an outsider. Their peaceful domesticity is interrupted when Jo falls pregnant after an affair with a black sailor. After the birth of the baby, Jo and Geoffrey are effectively co-parenting until Jo’s opportunistic mother re-emerges to stake her claim in her daughter’s life. Despite its depressing subject matter “A Taste of honey” entertains a blackly comic tone that keeps it from sliding into a draining melodrama. The film is a fascinating ‘slice-of-life’ view of working class life in Britain of the 60s, whose entrancing black and white cinematography, reminiscent of Bill Brandt’s photography of working class England, contrasts with the gauche and drab reality of the characters’ surrounds. This controversial film dealt with many taboo topics on the day - teen pregnancy, inter-racial romance, homosexuality, child abandonment, without excessive sermonising on the topics, typical of American moral dramas of the 1950s. Cast includes Dora Bryan, Rita Tushingham, Robert Stephens, Murray Melvin, Paul Danquah and David Boliver.

results.title: A Taste of energy
results.creator_credit: Edwin Scragg, Colonial Sugar Industry and Scope Films
results.brief_description: The Australian sugar industry, showing all stages of cane cultivation and harvesting, extraction and refining of sugar. Impressions of life in the sugar producing regions of Queensland and northern New South Wales and the place of sugar in the Australian economy.

results.title: A taste of China: cooking with Kenneth Lo
results.creator_credit: Eddie Joffe and Thames Video Collection
results.brief_description: Kenneth Lo, world famous Chinese chef and leading authority on Chinese food, is joined by actor Vincent Price on this Chinese cookery course. Chinese cuisine is one of the oldest in the world, with many contrasts in flavour, colour and texture. Kenneth Lo unlocks the secrets and mysteries of this cuisine and provides straightforward instructions for basic methods of preparing a Chinese family meal or elaborate banquet. Chefs from Lo’s cooking school appear on this video, preparing a range of delicious recipes.

results.title: A Taste of cherry = Ta'm e guilass
results.brief_description: Abbas Kiarostami’s `Taste of Cherry’, the 1997 Palme d’or winner at the Cannes Film Festival, follows his usual style of fiction bordering on documentary. A weary middle-aged man drives his car around looking for someone to bury him after he kills himself. He meets different people - Afghans, Kurds, a soldier, a cleric, a museum employee - all of whom try to dissuade him from his intent. This film presents a minimalist meditation on life and death, deliberately avoiding emotions or judgements. The ending is cut short due to a state prohibition on the depiction of suicide.

results.title: A Taste of Adelaide
results.creator_credit: Ron Way and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: An award-winning film of some of Adelaide’s fine restaurants and hotels; a tour laced together with delightful glimpses into some of the colourful, charming, little-known and well-known aspects of this unspoiled, unhurried city.

results.title: A Talent for Tony
results.creator_credit: Bruce Baker, Karl Holtsnider and Teleketics
results.brief_description: Parable, play and fantasy all combine to create for the younger child an experience in growth and faith. The father of five year old Tony is preparing for his art exhibition and sets his children to draw. Tony is unable to produce anything and retreats in fear, but with encouragement from his father the situation is resolved.
results.description: Parable, play and fantasy all combine to create for the younger child an experience in growth and faith. results.title: A Tale of two shamba's
results.creator_credit: Julian Sprio, Humphrey Swingler and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: Shamba is Swahili for small holding, and this is the story of two East African farmers. Joseph, who is part of a co-operative, prospers, but Peter, who neglects his farm for a job in the city, requires help from Joseph and the local bank. The services of the bank and the importance of co-operative farming in Kenya are emphasised.

results.title: A Tale of Two Cities
results.creator_credit: Michael E. Briant, Barry Letts, ABC-TV (Australia), Time-Life Television and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Sydney Carton, wastrel and dissolute, black sheep and fallen angel, whose words on the scaffold secure him a place in the quotation books, remains as potent a creation today as he was when Dickens’ poignant classic was first published. His ‘double’, Charles Darnay, who mirrors what Carton could have been and who wins the hand of Lucie whom Carton also loves, remains a satellite of goodness in this tale of sacrifice and hate. Their lives and fates, inextricably linked, merge again in the figure of Paul Shelley who brings them both to life in this authentic dramatisation.

results.title: A Tale of Two Cities
results.creator_credit: Jack Conway and David O. Selznick
results.brief_description: Based on Charles Dickens great novel, “A Tale of Two Cities” is a tale of turbulent times - the French revolution, recreated in breathtaking scale and painstaking detail. And it is a timeless tale - the story of two men in love with the same woman. Ronald Colman stars in what is perceived as the best role he ever played. “A Tale of Two Cities” is a tale of romance and revolution, politics and passion, but most of all it is a true classic for all time.
